posts.cooked:
Hi, I’m from team 8015. We are testing our elevator subsystem with 2 motors, and found out that the leader motor and the follower motor are not working properly. image 1114×364 49.4 KB Using Advantage Scope, we can see that the follower motor has a different supply voltage with the leader motor, causing a increasing difference in the positions of them. They even don’t start or stop moving sometimes. Even when we write a “follower” logic by ourselves by periodically getting the voltage of another motor, the problem still exists. Especially when PID is used during controlling. When using the logic on the elevator (especially closed-loop), the problem showed as the two sides rising out of sync, shaking and stretching the elevator.

image 1114×364 49.4 KB

image 1114×364 49.4 KB

Does anyone meet the same problem? It seems to be an issue of the logger which impacts all close-loop controlling…

link_counts.title: TalonFX follower command causing motors to fight each other

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
If your two motors are not mechanically coupled in a gear box, then you should not use following, as there’s no guarantee that the follower will ever reach the target. Running separate PID loops on each can work, but it can be risky, as there’s no guarantee that they move in sync when you do so. That issue is alleviated by using Motion Magic though.

Ideally, you should design your system so both motors are together in a gear box that ends up driving both sides; in that case, following works as expected. Otherwise, the correct solution for this mechanism is differential control , where you run one PID controller on moving the elevator up/down and another on making the difference between the two motors’ positions 0.

Is it possible to control a lead and follow in tuner x and what is the operating procedure for doing so. All our firmware is up do date and we are connected over radio. Thanks in advance!

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Follower is not a config in Phoenix 6, it’s a control request that needs to be actively applied to the device. You can launch multiple instances of Tuner X to control multiple motors at the same time.

posts.cooked:
TalonFX follower command causing motors to fight each other

We used this logic on separate gear boxes in past seasons and it works perfectly fine in years before 2025. Actually we saw that great teams like 6328 uses the same logic of follower on separate gear boxes and have a perfect performance… There must be something wrong. We tested both Falcon and Kraken, both Robot RIO 1, 2, and connecting Canivore. We even tried switching leader and follower, but things aren’t going better…

Why the problem is not happening in past years?

link_counts.title: TalonFX follower command causing motors to fight each other

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: A number of factors could affect things—mechanical differences (a bit more friction on one side or in one of the gearboxes), electrical differences (higher wire resistance for one of the motors, or bad connection at the PDP / PDH ), etc. There are a lot of disturbances and sources of error with an elevator in this setup, so there’s a lot that can change between seasons despite similar mechanical setups.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: I would like to provide a quick clarification on this, since I’ve been asked a few times now if differential is necessary for some COTS elevators with tight, rigid coupling between the two sides. If you can put one side of the elevator in coast and drive just the other side, and the coasting side does not significantly lag behind, then regular Follower will be sufficient. Otherwise, at a minimum you will want to control both sides independently with Motion Magic, if not use differential control.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We used Motion control on both sides of our arm last year, and it worked wonderfully.  That was before the differential control was really a thing and documented.  I would do the same even now, because just copying over the motion magic constants and then sending the motors the same command is very easy to remember how to do.

Frankly, just having a checkbox or a dropdown to ‘link’ two motors to using the same motion magic info and setpoints would be awesome.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
If you want to use differential, the easiest way to set it up is to use one of our differential mechanisms, either simple (free and works on CAN 2.0) or the full mechanism (requires Pro and CANivore). You construct it by passing in the two motors and whether their directions align. The first motor will become the leader, and the second will be the DifferentialFollower.

From there, you should apply all your regular device configs, then call m_differential.applyConfigs() to apply the configs unique to the differential mechanism. From there, you can just set the control of the differential mechanism to control the entire system. We have an optional periodic() method you can call to automatically check for fault conditions and disable to prevent hardware damage, as well as ways to check and clear the error, but you can also do that yourself.

As for setting up differential, there are two axes; the “average” axis is the average of the two motors’ positions and represents the up/down movement of the elevator, and the “differential” or “difference” axis is the difference between the two motor positions. You would typically use Slot0 for the average axis and Slot1 for the differential axis. Tune the average axis (which can be done using SysId) and use something like Motion Magic to target a vertical height, then manually tune the difference axis (which may just need a kS and kP) to target a position difference of 0.
